abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second Rural Poverty
            Alleviation and Natural Resource Management Project is rated
            as satisfactory, sustainability as likely, institutional
            development impact as modest, bank performance as
            satisfactory, and borrower performance as satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned from the implementation of the project
            include: 1) The project ratified the validity of the
            proposal to tackle poverty through an improvement in both
            agricultural and non-agricultural activities. 2) The
            development of non-agricultural activities needs to be based
            on detailed feasibility studies, especially concerning the
            marketing of output which should be incorporated into the
            analysis from the earliest stage of identification and
            preparation. 3) Sub-project proposals presented for
            financing should be subject to strict selection criteria
            which puts emphasis on the quality of the analysis of the
            technical, economic, and social viability of the proposals.
            4) An integrated approach must be made to farm development.
            Land degradation must be approached from the perspective of
            the farm as a whole, rather than from that of individual
            crops, and sustainable production systems must be defined
            and introduced according to farm's capabilities. 5) The
            tendency in this pilot project was to concentrate on-farm
            development efforts on those aspects of the production
            system likely to produce short-term benefits, to the
            detriment of natural resource conservation activities that
            have longer-term returns.
